wikipedia_page.main: Frances Julia Stewart (born 4 August 1940) is professor emeritus of development economics and director of the Centre for Research on Inequality, Human Security and Ethnicity (CRISE), University of Oxford. A pre-eminent development economist, she was named one of fifty outstanding technological leaders for 2003 by Scientific American. She was president of the Human Development and Capability Association from 2008–2010.

One of the leading critics on the 'greed' argument is Frances Stewart. In her article 'Horizontal Inequalities: A neglected Dimension of Development,' she stresses the need to focus on the grievances of the populations, since too much focus on inequality between individuals is dangerous for successful development. By using nine case studies she proves how horizontal inequalities have led to violent conflict.

In Oxford, in 1993 Frances Stewart was appointed director of Queen Elizabeth House and encouraged to transform it into a university department: the M.Phil. in Development Studies followed in 1996. Since 2007-8, Queen Elizabeth House has been ranked first nationally for its research in development studies."Oxford Department of International Development" Between 2004-7, during her own term as director of Queen Elizabeth House,Oxford Department of International Development Harriss-White co-organised Queen Elizabeth House's 50th anniversary celebrations,"Development Studies at the University of Oxford" supported the consolidation of research groups focussing on social and human development, collaborated in developing an Oxford base for Indian early career researchers, co-organised Queen Elizabeth House's move of site and the building of an extension. She then chaired the first Research Assessment Exercise in Development Studies"Research Assessment Exercise 2007" nationally for the Higher Education Funding Council for England and refused a civil honour. Meanwhile, in 2005, the year when Dr Manmohan Singh, then India's Prime Minister, had received his honorary degree from Oxford, she was asked to set up a multi-disciplinary masters in the study of India, in Oxford's School of Interdisciplinary Area Studies."School of Interdisciplinary Area Studies, University of Oxford" Starting in 2008, it later appeared this was the first"The Hindu, 25 February 2011" such degree in the world. In this she mainstreamed the multi-disciplinary study of India's environment, again thought to be an innovation in a non-environmental master's degree. In retirement from Oxford, she holds a visiting professorship in the Centre for Informal Sector and Labour Studies in Jawaharlal Nehru University, India,"Barbara Harriss-White, Centre for Informal Sector and Labour Studies, Jawaharlal Nehru University, India" a professorial research associateship at SOAS, University of London,"Barbara Harriss-White, Department of Development Studies, SOAS, University of London" and is an emeritus fellow at Wolfson College, Oxford"Barbara Harriss-White, Wolfson College, Oxford" where she convenes the South Asia Research Cluster.
